coredata.dc:title: Molecular bridges stabilize lithium metal anode and solid-state electrolyte interface

coredata.dc:description: Rechargeable solid-state lithium metal battery (SSLMB) with high safety and energy density is regarded as one of the most promising candidates for next-generation energy-storage systems. However, the long-term interfacial stability between lithium metal anode and solid-state electrolyte is still a great challenge. Herein we propose an interfacial “molecular bridge” strategy to improve the interfacial adhesion between lithium metal anode and solid-state electrolyte by chemical bonding. As consequence, the lithium metal anode shows high interfacial wettability with solid-state electrolyte film, and Li/Li symmetrical cells display outstanding cycling stability with reduced polarization voltage, stable interfacial resistance, and dendrite-free lithium surface. In addition, high voltage LiCoO2 (LCO)/Li full cells show enhanced cycling stability and superior rate capability. Moreover, the LCO/Li pouch cell exhibits excellent durability in harsh operating conditions such as bending and shearing. This scalable, simple and feasible interfacial-stabilization strategy offers a new route to the development and practical application of high-performance SSLMB.

Synthesis of Semi-SN-SE electrolyte and interfacial “molecular bridges”
Formation and characterization of interfacial “molecular bridges”
Performance and analysis of Li/Li symmetric cells

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Schematic of the formation process of interfacial “molecular bridges” between Li metal anode and Semi-SN-SE.

(a) Top-view SEM image and (b-d) EDS-mapping of A151-Li anode. The top inset of (a) shows the optical photograph of A151-Li anode. (e) FTIR spectra of A151 molecule, pristine Li and A151-Li anodes. (f) Si 2p XPS spectra of pristine Li and A151-Li anodes. (g) The reaction mechanism between A151 molecule and Li metal anode.

(a) Top-view SEM image of Semi-SN-SE. (b) Ionic conductivity of the Semi-SN-SE versus temperature. (c) LSV curves of Semi-SN-SE electrolyte based on different working electrodes. The interface contacts state of Semi-SN-SE with (d) pristine Li and (e) A151-Li anodes. (f) FTIR spectra of PETEA monomer, A151 molecule, and PETEA-A151 hybrid after thermal polymerization.

Impedance spectra of Li/Li symmetric cells with (a) pristine Li and (b) A151-Li anodes before cycling, and the insets show the equivalent circuit. (c) Galvanostatic charge/discharge curves of Li/Li symmetric cells with pristine Li and A151-Li anodes, where the inset shows the partially enlarged view at different cycling times. (d, e) Optical photographs and the corresponding SEM images of pristine Li and A151-Li anodes after 200 cycles. (f) Schematic of action mechanism of interfacial molecular bridges during cycling.

Electrochemical properties of LCO/Li cells with (a, c, e) pristine Li and (b, d, f) A151-Li anodes. (a, b) Cycling performance and Coulombic efficiency, (c, d) charge–discharge voltage profiles and (e, f) rate capability.

head.ce:title: Molecular bridges stabilize lithium metal anode and solid-state electrolyte interface

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: MIIT Key Laboratory of Critical Materials Technology for New Energy Conversion and Storage, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: MIIT Key Laboratory of Critical Materials Technology for New Energy Conversion and Storage
School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: MIIT Key Laboratory of Critical Materials Technology for New Energy Conversion and Storage, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: These authors contributed equally to this work.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Rechargeable solid-state lithium metal battery (SSLMB) with high safety and energy density is regarded as one of the most promising candidates for next-generation energy-storage systems. However, the long-term interfacial stability between lithium metal anode and solid-state electrolyte is still a great challenge. Herein we propose an interfacial “molecular bridge” strategy to improve the interfacial adhesion between lithium metal anode and solid-state electrolyte by chemical bonding. As consequence, the lithium metal anode shows high interfacial wettability with solid-state electrolyte film, and Li/Li symmetrical cells display outstanding cycling stability with reduced polarization voltage, stable interfacial resistance, and dendrite-free lithium surface. In addition, high voltage LiCoO2 (LCO)/Li full cells show enhanced cycling stability and superior rate capability. Moreover, the LCO/Li pouch cell exhibits excellent durability in harsh operating conditions such as bending and shearing. This scalable, simple and feasible interfacial-stabilization strategy offers a new route to the development and practical application of high-performance SSLMB.

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been widely used in portable electronic equipment, electric vehicle (EV) industry, and smart grid [1–4]. However, the flammable organic carbonate liquid electrolyte in commercial LIBs results in great potential safety hazards [5–7]. Solid-state lithium metal battery (SSLMB) is one of the most optimal solutions for next-generation energy-storage systems due to the advantages of high safety and high energy density [8–10]. As the important component of SSLMB, the physico-chemical properties of SSE are critical to the electrochemical performance of SSLMB [11–13]. Ideal SSE should have sufficiently high room temperature ionic conductivity, excellent electrochemical stability, high mechanical strength, and favorable interfacial compatibility with positive and negative electrodes [14–16]. Furthermore, the close and stable solid–solid contact between SSE and Li metal anode is a tremendous challenge for the development of high-performance SSLMB because of the huge volume effect of Li metal anode during repeated cycling [17–20].

Succinonitrile (SN, N≡C(CH2)2C≡N) based plastic crystal electrolyte (SN-PCE) is a novel and attractive solid-state ionic conductor due to the high oxidative resistance (up to 5.5 V) and good room temperature ionic conductivity (reaching 3.0 mS cm−1) [21–23]. However, the practical application of SN-PCE in SSLMB is still limited by the poor chemical stability with Li metal anode and weak mechanical strength [24–27]. Aiming to address the above tricky issues, the researchers have made great progress and devoted significant efforts. High concentration lithium salt and film-forming additive have been proved effective to inhibit the interfacial side reactions by increasing the solvation ratio or constructing stable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film [28–30]. Our recent works confirm that dual-lithium salt coupled fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) can construct a high durable organic–inorganic hybrid SEI film to improve the interfacial chemical stability [31,32]. The mechanical strength of SN-PCEs can be generally enhanced by introducing crosslinked polymer network as physical skeleton via in-situ polymerization technology [33–35]. It has been confirmed that the mechanical bendability of SN-PCE can be greatly improved with the semi-interpenetrating polymer network consisting of ultraviolet (UV)-crosslinked ethoxylated trimethylolpropane triacrylate (ETPTA) polymer network and polyvinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene (PVDF) liner polymer [36]. However, most researches focus on enhancing the chemical stability and mechanical strength, and less attention was paid to reinforcing the interfacial contact stability between in-situ cured SN-PCEs and Li metal anode.

Silane coupling agent (SCA) as a popular interface adhesion promoter has been widely used in inorganic–organic composite materials [37–39]. Commonly, SCA contains three inorganic-reactive alkoxy groups (methoxy or ethoxy) and one organic-reactive group (vinyl, epoxy, amino and so on), which can respectively bond with inorganic and organic materials and thus effectively improve the interfacial wettability, compatibility, and mechanical strength of inorganic–organic composite materials [38]. In the field of ceramic-polymer composite SSE, the dispersion uniformity of ceramic fillers in the polymer matrix can be greatly enhanced after the fillers modified with SCA [40]. Besides, the enhanced interfacial bonding between ceramic and polymer matrix can remarkably reinforce the mechanical strength of composite SSE [41]. Recently, Z. Guo et. al confirmed that 3-methacryloxypropyltrimethoxysilane (MPS, one of SCAs) can be grafted on Li surface through Si-O-Li covalent bond by reacting with the impurity phase LiOH on Li surface, providing good interface protection in liquid electrolyte system [42]. Therefore, SCAs are expected to improve the interfacial adhesion between in-situ cured SN-PCEs and Li metal anode through chemical bonding.

Herein, we report a simple and feasible “molecular bridge” strategy to realize the high interfacial contact stability between in-situ cured SN-PCEs and Li metal anode. At first, the inorganic-reaction groups of SCAs molecules react with the impurity LiOH on the Li surface, forming Si-O-Li covalent bond. Then, during the in-situ polymerization of electrolyte precursor solutions, the organic-reaction groups of grafted SCA molecules copolymerize with the organic monomer, generating interfacial “molecular bridges” mainly composed of C-C and Si-O-Li covalent bonds. The presence of “molecular bridges” greatly improves the interfacial wettability between Li metal anode and solid-state electrolyte. The modified Li/Li symmetric cell shows low interface impedance (∼85 Ω) before cycling, stable polarization voltage (∼15 mV), long cycling life (800 h) and dendrite-free at the current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 with a fixed capacity of 0.1 mAh cm−2. The high voltage LiCoO2 (LCO)/Li cell with interfacial “molecular bridges” delivers a discharge specific capacity of 154.7 mAh g−1 after 160 cycles at 0.5C corresponding to a capacity retention of 95.8%. In addition, it can maintain an ideal discharge specific capacity of 154.8 mAh g−1 at a high rate of 5C. Meanwhile, the modified LCO/Li pouch cells show high durability and safety under various harsh conditions.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Surface grafting reaction of silane coupling agent with Li metal
ce:section.ce:para: Fresh Li foil (∼300 µm, China Energy Lithium Co., Ltd.) was dipping in vinyltriethoxy silane A151 (CH2 = CHSi(OCH2CH3)3, 97%, Aladdin) and anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF) hybrid solutions for 30 min, where the volume ratio of vinyltriethoxy silane A151 and THF is 1:19. Then, Li foil was taken out and heated (∼100 ℃) for 1 h to remove the THF solvent. After that, the as prepared Li foil was marked as A151-Li. The preparation process was carried out in the argon-filled glove box (O2 and H2O content less than 0.5 ppm, Mikrouna).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of Semi-SN-SE electrolyte and interfacial “molecular bridges”
ce:section.ce:para: Firstly, microporous polyvinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene (PVDF-HFP) membranes were prepared by the phase-inversion method. PVDF-HFP powders (Mw = 640,000, Aladdin) were dispersed in acetone solvent with a mass ratio of 1:10 and stirred at 55 ℃ to form a homogeneous solution. Then, deionized water was added to the above homogeneous solution with a mass ratio of 1:24 stirred at 55 ℃ for 30 min and naturally cooling to room temperature under stirring. After that, the mixed solution was casted on the polypropylene film by a small coater, naturally drying for 6 h at room temperature, and then vacuum drying for 6 h at 80 ℃. The dry PVDF-HFP membranes were punched into a round piece with a diameter of 16.5 mm and stored in glove box for standby. Secondly, the curing precursor solution was prepared by mixing SN-DLi-FEC electrolyte solution, pentaerythritol tetraacrylate (PETEA) monomer and thermal initiator (2,2′-Azobis(2-methylpropionitrile), AIBN) with a mass ratio of 85:15:1 and stirred for 30 min, where the molar ratio of SN: lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI): lithium difluoro(oxalate)borate (LiODFB) and volume ratio of FEC in SN-DLi-FEC are 20:0.95:0.05 and 9.09 vol%, respectively. Thirdly, the as prepared PVDF-HFP membranes were dipped in the curing precursor solution for a few minutes and then placed on the heating stage for 1 h at 70 ℃ to realize in-situ polymerization of PETEA monomer. The as prepared SN-based solid-state electrolyte film with semi interpenetrating network structure (PVDF-HFP line polymer coupled PETEA polymer network) was marked as Semi-SN-SE. Similarly, the interfacial “molecular bridges” were constructed by in-situ curing Semi-SN-SE electrolyte on the surface of A151-Li.

The ionic conductivity of Semi-SN-SE in the temperature range of 25 ∼ 80 ℃ was investigated by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) using an electrochemical station (PARSTAT 2273, Princeton Applied Research) in the frequency range of 106 ∼ 1 Hz with an AC amplitude of ± 5 mV. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) method was adopted to test the electrochemical stability of electrolyte precursor solution and Semi-SN-SE with a scanning rate of 0.5 mV s−1 in the voltage range from open circuit voltage to 6 V on a CHI640D electrochemical station, where aluminum (Al) foil or carbon coated Al foil was used as working electrode and Li foil was used as reference electrode and counter electrode. The lithium-ion transference number (TLi +) of Semi-SN-SE was measured through chronoamperometry test on the A151-Li/Semi-SN-SE/A151-Li symmetric cell based on the following equation:

Where the ΔV is the constant DC polarization potential of 10 mV; I0 and Iss are the initial and steady-state currents, respectively, and R0 and Rss represent the initial and steady-state interface resistances before and after the polarization.

The evolution rules of interfacial resistance of Li/Semi-SN-SE/Li symmetric cells with pristine Li and A151-Li anodes before and after the galvanostatic charge/discharge cycling (0.1 mA cm−2 for 0.1 mAh cm−2) were evaluated by EIS. The critical current densities (CCDs)of Li/Semi-SN-SE/Li and A151-Li/Semi-SN-SE/A151-Li symmetric cells were tested by gradually increasing the charge/discharge current density from 0.05 mA cm−2 to 1.0 mA cm−2. The Coulombic efficiencies of Li/Semi-SN-SE/Cu and A151-Li/Semi-SN-SE/Cu half-cells were collected through discharging for 1 h and then charging to 1 V at the current density of 0.1 mA cm−2. The high voltage LiCoO2 (LCO) cathode consisting of active material, conductive additive (super P) and binder agent (PVDF) with a mass ratio of 8:1:1 was prepared by slurry casting method, and the mass loading of the active material is about 2.0 ∼ 2.5 mg cm−2. To prepare LCO/Semi-SN-SE/A151-Li full cells, the as prepared LCO cathode, PVDF-HFP membrane, A151-Li anode and a certain of curing precursor solution were sealed in the LIR2025-type coin cell, and then heated for 1 h at 70 ℃ to obtain SSLMB. The cyclic performance (0.5C charge/discharge) and rate capability (0.1C to 5C) of LCO/Semi-SN-SE/A151-Li full cells were tested by Neware coin cell battery testing system (CT-4008 T 5 V-10 mA) at room temperature.

The surface morphology and element distribution of A151-Li were verified by field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, TESAN VEGA 3 SBH) and energy dispersion spectrum (EDS)-mapping. The surface functional group property of A151-Li was analyzed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, ThermoFisher Scientific Nicolet iS10) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ThermoFisher ESCALAB 250XI). The surface morphology of PVDF-HFP membrane and Semi-SN-SE electrolyte and the interfacial contact state of Semi-SN-SE with Li anode were performed by FE-SEM. The interaction of A151 and PETEA monomer was also tested by FTIR technology. The surface morphology of pristine Li and A151-Li anodes after cycling in Li/Li symmetric cells was analyzed by FE-SEM.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Formation and characterization of interfacial “molecular bridges”
ce:section.ce:para: Fig. 1 shows the schematic illustration of the formation process of interfacial “molecular bridges” between Li metal anode and solid-state electrolyte. After Li metal anode reacting with A151/THF solution, Si-O-Li covalent bonds were successfully constructed on the surface of A151-Li anode, and the organic reaction groups of A151 molecule were arranged on the side away from the Li anode [42,43]. Then, during in-situ polymerization of electrolyte precursor solution, the PETEA monomer copolymerized with the terminal unsaturated C–C double bond of the organic reaction groups of A151 molecule on the surface of Li anode. Therefore, interfacial “molecular bridges” can be established between Li metal anode and Semi-SN-SE by C-C and Si-O-Li covalent bonds, which can effectively promote the interfacial adhesion properties. By comparation, there was weak interfacial interaction between pristine Li metal anode and Semi-SN-SE, causing poor interfacial contact.

To understand the formation process of A151 molecule layer on the surface Li metal anode, field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) and energy dispersion spectrum (EDS)-mapping were employed to obtain the morphology and element dispersion of A151-Li anode. Fig. 2
a shows the surface SEM image of A151-Li anode and the inset shows the optical photograph. There was no significant change on morphology and surface colors. It is demonstrated that the solution dipping has no harmful effect on the Li metal anode. The uniform distribution of Si, O, and C elements indicates that A151 molecule layer was successfully constructed on the Li metal anode surface after the short dipping (Fig. 2 b-d). This conclusion was further confirmed by fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analysis as shown in Fig. 2 e, where the typical stretching vibration absorption (1084 cm−1, 1106 cm−1, and 1163 cm−1) of Si-O bond appears on the surface of A151-Li [38,42]. Moreover, the binding energy of A151-Li anode surface was further studied by X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS). Fig. 2 f shows the high-resolution Si 2p comparison of pristine Li and A151-Li anodes. No obvious signal can be observed in the Si 2p spectra of pristine Li anode. In contrast, three peaks at 102.1 eV, 101.5 eV, and 100.7 eV can be figured out in the Si 2p spectrum of A151-Li anode, corresponding to Si-O-Si, O-Si-C, and Si-O-Li bonding, respectively [39]. The presence of Si-O-Li bonding indicates the successful reaction of A151 molecule with impurity phase LiOH on the surface of Li metal anode, and the presence of Si-O-Si bonding should be attributed to the interaction of adjacent A151 molecules. Based on the above-mentioned analyses, Fig. 2 g shows the possible reaction mechanism of A151 molecule on the Li anode surface.

As shown in Fig. S1 , the PVDF-HFP membrane shows flourishing hole structure, which is favorable for the impregnation of the electrolyte precursor solution and the maintenance of ionic conductivity after in-situ polymerization [44,45]. As expected, solid-state electrolyte Semi-SN-SE with high densification was successfully constructed after in-situ polymerization (Fig. 3
a). In addition, Semi-SN-SE shows high flexibility and enhanced mechanical strength (tensile strength is about 2.14 MPa), which are significant for the manufaction and practical application ( Fig. S2 and Fig. S3 ) [17,46]. The impedance spectra and the corresponding ionic conductivity of Semi-SN-SE at different temperatures (25 ℃ to 80 ℃) are shown in Fig. S4 and Fig. 3 b. The ionic conductivity of Semi-SN-SE is about 2.23 mS cm−1 at ambient temperature and gradually increase with the temperature, which is near to that of liquid electrolyte. The oxidation potentials of electrolyte precursor solution and Semi-SN-SE were tested by LSV method. As shown in Fig. 3 c, the oxidative potential of Semi-SN-SE is about 5.20 V when Al foil as the working electrode, which is higher than that of electrolyte precursor solution (4.75 V, Fig. S5 ), suggesting that the in-situ polymer network can effectively enhance the electrochemical stability of Semi-SN-SE. In addition, the oxidation potential of Semi-SN-SE still is up to 4.91 V when matching with carbon coated Al foil, indicating good compatibility with high voltage cathode materials, which is beneficial for the energy density of battery [47,48]. In addition, Semi-SN-SE shows high lithium-ion transference number (TLi +) of 0.54 ( Fig. S6 ), which is favorable to reduce the concentration gradient of Li+ and thus contributes to the uniform deposition and stripping behavior of Li anode. Meanwhile, Semi-SN-SE shows superior thermal stability, and the weight loss is less than 5 % before 100 ℃ as shown in Fig. S7 , which greatly broadens the operating temperature range and application fields of the battery system.

Interfacial adhesion property is a crucial factor for solid-state electrolyte film and Li metal anode interface [49,50]. Fig. 3 d and 3e exhibit the interfacial contact state of Semi-SN-SE film with pristine Li and A151-Li after the in-situ polymerization process. Compared with the high interfacial wettability between electrolyte precursor solution and Li anode, a large interface gap can be observed at the interface of Semi-SN-SE and pristine Li anode (Fig. 3 d), which should be arised from the low interaction between Li anode and the in-situ polymer network of Semi-SN-SE. The poor interfacial contact will lead to the increase of local current density and then the non-uniform Li metal deposition and stripping behavior [51]. In contrast, the interface of Semi-SN-SE and A151-Li is conformal and tight without any interface gaps. The favorable interfacial contact should be attributed to the in-situ copolymerization of PETEA monomer and the C–C double bond of A151 molecule. This assumption can be verified by FTIR analysis, as shown in Fig. 3 f, the stretching vibration absorption of C–C double bond of A151 molecule (1599 cm−1) and PETEA monomer (1634 cm−1 and 1619 cm−1) disappeared when their mixed solution (1:1 mass ratio) undergoes the same polymerization conditions with electrolyte precursor. Therefore, interfacial “molecular bridges” can be formed by the chemical bonding of A151 molecule with Li metal anode and Semi-SN-SE film, which can effectively enhance the interfacial adhesion. It is believed that the interfacial “molecular bridges” are favorable for the interfacial stability and reaction kinetics between solid-state electrolyte and Li metal anode.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Performance and analysis of Li/Li symmetric cells
ce:section.ce:para:
The Li/Li symmetric cells were prepared to evaluate the influence of “molecular bridges” on interfacial compatibility between Li metal anode and Semi-SN-SE. The EIS spectra of Li/Li symmetric cells with pristine Li and A151-Li anodes before cycling are presented in Fig. 4
a and 4b. The inset shows the equivalent circuit of symmetric cell, where the R0, R1, C1 represent ohmic resistance, interface impedance and interface capacitance, respectively. Obviously, the initial interface impedance of symmetric cell with pristine Li anode is about 200 Ω and gradually increases along with the standing time due to the poor interfacial adhesion. By contrast, the interface impedance of symmetric cell with A151-Li anode is relatively low and stable (∼85 Ω). The charge/discharge cycling performance of Li/Li symmetric cells were carried out and the corresponding voltage–time curves are shown in Fig. 4 c. The polarization voltage of symmetric cell with pristine Li at the initial stage is about 42 mV and gradually reduces during the subsequent cycles. The sharp drop of polarization voltage happens at 275 h, which is ascribed to the inner short circuit and verified by the gradually decrease of interfacial impedance ( Fig. S8
a) [52–54]. As expected, the A151-Li/Semi-SN-SE/A151-Li symmetric cell shows a low and smooth initial polarization voltage (∼15 mV) and quite stable interfacial impedance ( Fig. S8
b). In addition, an ultra-long life-span over 800 h can be achieved without significant change of polarization voltage. Moreover, the surface of pristine Li anode becomes uneven, rough and filled with dendrite Li after 200 cycles (Fig. 4 d and Fig. S9
a). However, the A151-Li maintains smooth and compact surface without any dendrite Li after 200 cycles (Fig. 4 e and Fig. S9
b) and 400 cycles ( Fig. S10 ), proving that the presence of interfacial molecular bridges can effectively enhance the uniformity of Li during electrochemical deposition and stripping [55–57]. As an important parameter to evaluate the interfacial compatibility between solid-state electrolyte and Li anode, the critical current density (CCD) of A151-Li/Semi-SN-SE/A151-Li symmetric cell reaches 0.9 mA cm−2 ( Fig. S11 ). In contrast, the CCD of Li/Semi-SN-SE/Li symmetric cell is only 0.2 mA cm−2. The A151-Li/Semi-SN-SE/Cu half-cell also displays a relatively higher initial Coulombic efficiency (82.5 %, Fig. S12
b) than that of Li/Semi-SN-SE/Cu half-cell (78.1 %, Fig. S12
a). According to results above, Fig. 4 f shows the action mechanism of interfacial “molecular bridges” on the interface between Li anode and solid-state electrolyte during cycling. Compared with the interface of pristine Li and Semi-SN-SE, the interfacial “molecular bridges” can effectively improve the interfacial adhesion between A151-Li anode and Semi-SN-SE, increase the active contact area and reduce local current density, inducing the uniform distribution of lithium-ion flow and realizing the homogeneous and dendrite-free deposition/stripping behavior.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Performance and analysis of LiCoO2/Li cells
ce:section.ce:para:
In order to further evaluate the electrochemical stability of Semi-SN-SE and interfacial “molecular bridges”, the LiCoO2 (LCO)/Li solid-state cells were prepared based on in-situ polymerization technology. Fig. S13
b shows the SEM image of the LCO cathode after in-situ polymerization of the electrolyte precursor solution. Compared with the bare LCO cathode ( Fig. S13
a), the pores around the active material particles are basically filled with the solidified electrolyte as shown in the EDS mappings ( Fig. S13
c). The tight interfacial contact is beneficial for the transfer of lithium-ion between the LCO cathode and the solid-state electrolyte [58–60]. Fig. 5
a displays the cycling performance of the LCO/pristine Li cell at 0.5C (initial 3 cycles at 0.1C for activation), and the initial discharge specific capacity and Coulombic efficiency are 160.8 mAh g−1 and 90.7 %, respectively. After activation process, the discharge specific capacity is about 155.4 mAh g−1 at 0.5C and then sharply decreases during the next 80 cycles. The capacity retention of LCO/pristine Li cell is only 32.8 % after 160 cycles, which should be ascribed to the poor interfacial compatibility between pristine Li and Semi-SN-SE. By comparison, the initial discharge specific capacity and Coulombic efficiency of the LCO/A151-Li cell are 164.5 mAh g−1 and 93.5 %, which is superior to those of LCO/pristine Li cell. The LCO/A151-Li cell can deliver a high discharge specific capacity about 161.5 mAh g−1 at 0.5C and maintain an improved capacity retention of 95.8 % after 160 cycles. As shown in Fig. 5 c, the polarization voltage of the LCO/pristine Li cell increases rapidly, especially after 80 cycles, which is consistent with the poor cycling performance. By contrast, polarization voltage was quite stable in LCO/A151-Li cell during cycling (Fig. 5 d). As shown in Fig. 5 e-f and Figs. S14
a-b, the LCO/pristine Li cell shows poor rate capability, high polarization voltage and unstable Coulombic efficiency. In contrast, the LCO/A151-Li cell shows excellent rate capability, lower polarization voltage, stable Coulombic efficiency, and the discharge specific capacity at the high rate of 5C is up to 154.8 mAh g−1. The electrochemical performance of LCO/Semi-SN-SE/A151-Li cells is superior than previously published works (Table S1). Moreover, the LCO/Li pouch cells equipped with Semi-SN-SE and A151-Li anode show high reliability and safety, which can provide stable electrical power output even in repeated bending and shearing states ( Fig. S15 ).

In conclusion, the interfacial “molecular bridges” mainly composed of C-C and Si-O-Li covalent bonds were created by the reaction of SCAs molecule with lithium metal anode and solid-state electrolyte, which can effectively enhance the interfacial wettability and stability between Li anode and solid-state electrolyte film. As a result, the interface impedance and the polarization voltage of the symmetric cells with A151-Li anode before cycling are significantly reduced. Meanwhile, the ultra-long cycling stability and dendrite-free lithium surface is achieved. Besides, the LCO/Li full cells show improved discharge specific capacity, enhanced capacity retention and superior rate capability, and the pouch cells also exhibit outstanding durability under harsh operating conditions.

ce:conflict-of-interest.ce:para: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
